channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Perl for High Performance; Senior Developer, West London
item.description: Do you know how to solve problems in terms of queues and caches? Does the idea of truly scaling your architecture on AWS excite you? Not fazed by designing your workloads to be distributed?

item.title: Largest Perl team in London with beautiful Docklands offices
item.description: Large, dynamic Perl team in Canary Wharf looking for mid-level and senior developers. Run by a Perl-loving CTO in beautiful offices with a great view over Canary Wharf, the company manages one legacy Perl codebase and a whole bunch of very new, very shiny, and very modern codebases that power the market-leading solution in their particular area. Free breakfast, too, for some values of breakfast.

item.title: Do some good in the world â€“ Perl developers required for a charity and giving-focused team in Kent, UK
item.description: Want to do something good for once? Join the Kickstarter of the charity world, supporting activists and causes around the world. Youâ€™ll be working in Perl to support a range of their highly successful charity and giving-focused projects.

item.title: London Perl Workshop 2018
item.description: Saturday 3rd November 2018 London

item.title: Swiss Perl Workshop
item.description: September 7-8, 2018 Bern.

item.title: Nordic Perl Workshop and MojoConf 2018
item.description: September 6-7, 2018, Oslo.

item.title: The Perl Conference in Europe
item.description: August 15-17, 2018, Glasgow. The Call for Papers is open.

item.title: NLPW - Dutch Perl Workshop 2018
item.description: July 7, 2018, Arnhem, The Netherlands

item.title: The Perl Conference in North America
item.description: June 17-22, 2018, Salt Lake City.

item.title: French Perl Workshop
item.description: May 18-19, 2018, Paris.

item.title: A decade of classes in Lausanne
item.description: May 14-18, 2018, Lausanne. Five training classes by Damian.

item.title: The Perl Conference Newsletter: May 13, 2018
item.description: Discount pricing ends May 18th! Conference and Tutorial schedule posted

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Rakudo Star Release 2018.04
item.description: In case you are not familiar with the naming convention of the Rakudo team, the Rakudo Star contains the Perl 6 compiler/interpreter, documentation and a bunch of third-party modules.

item.title: 2018.19 The-Six-Percent Solution
item.description: Your weekly awesome of Perl 6.

item.title: Split up and flatten a CSV file
item.description: I wander if this was a real task or just the homework assignment of someone and if I've ruined the homework of some Perl teacher now by publishing an answer...

item.title: Grant Report : Improving Perl 6 Documentation - April 2018
Maintaining Perl 5 (Tony Cook): April 2018 Grant Report
How to become CPAN contributor
item.description: Mohammad, the most prolific CPAN contributor in the resent years, has a few suggestions with an easy way into contributing to a CPAN module. He also offers his personal help to get you moving.

item.title: What's happening with DBD::Oracle?
item.description: 'Whilst I have no interest in adoption DBD::Oracle, I am interested in a new "official release" so am curious who's out there using it?'

item.title: YAML.pm 1.25 Changelog
item.description: This release contains a lot of little bug fixes, so make sure you test your code with this module before you install it in production.

item.title: PrePan
item.description: PerlPan was designed to allow people to get feedback before the release a new module to CPAN. Is it still used?

item.title: What's new on CPAN - April 2018
item.description: The monthly collection of awesome stuff on CPAN. For example Geo::Privacy provides lookups for EU and GDPR countries

item.title: CPAN Testers at the Perl Toolchain Summit 2018
item.description: The primary goal of the CPAN Testers is testing CPAN modules on a variety of different OSes and Perl versions. It is also used to test development Perl versions to see if they are backwards compatible with existing CPAN code. Doug worked on the stability and the performance of the server collecting the data from all the machines testing CPAN modules.

item.title: Clumping
item.description: How to find out the dependencies list of a CPAN module or your code-base? What can you do if your code has a huge list of dependencies? Inlining? lumping? clumping? What is that and? How does it work? What problems arise?

item.title: Looking at the Lispy side of Perl
item.description: Lambdas and higher-order functions in Perl. One of the commenters pointing at this excellent presentation by Damian Conway.

item.title: Moose
item.description: The flood of Moose-related articles continues.

item.title: Announcing The London Perl Workshop 2018
item.description: The London Perl Workshop (LPW) takes place this year on Saturday 3rd Nov at the usual place of The University of Westminster's Cavendish Campus. You are encouraged to submit your talk proposals now, or if you have already feel free to submit another.

item.title: #355 - Perl at Craft
item.description:
Hi there!

Last week I was at the Craft Conference in Budapest. It was awesome and I've also met several Perl hackers.

Both Simon Wardley and Damian Conway gave keynote speeches. Paul Fenwick and Bill Odom gave regular talks though unfortunately I've missed the last one. Videos will be available in the coming days.

Damian even showed some Perl (both 5 and 6) during his talk to the amazement of about 2,000 people.

Oh, and I also met Mel Conway. You know of Conway's law.

I wish you a great week!
